de.uni.bamberg.wiai.minf.forflow.datagenerator.view.message
Class ErrorMessage

java.lang.Object
  java.awt.Component
      java.awt.Container
          java.awt.Window
              java.awt.Dialog
                  javax.swing.JDialog
                      de.uni.bamberg.wiai.minf.forflow.datagenerator.view.message.ErrorMessage
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, javax.accessibility.Accessible, javax.swing.RootPaneContainer, javax.swing.WindowConstants
public final class ErrorMessage
extends javax.swing.JDialog

This class extends behaviour from JDialog and is used to display any exception that might occur during runtime. The application is based on Java Swing and printing messages to console are not sufficient enough or not the proper way dealing with this. To bridge that gap, a more sophisticated way is desirable and we do this with an error message dialog. The dialog itself can be adjusted in several ways.

The message not only is displayed to the user, but it's also possible to create a log file. A flag controls the setting of the log mechanism and it's anytime possible to change it, at runtime, of course.

Here an example of such an error dialog.

Since:
May/05/09
Version:
0.1
Author:
Michael Munz
See Also:
Serialized Form

Method Detail

getInstance

public static ErrorMessage getInstance()
ErrorMessage class is based on Singelton pattern. To get an instance you've to call this method. It then creates an object only once and returns the reference.

Returns:
instance of error message

getInstance

public static ErrorMessage getInstance(boolean log)
ErrorMessage class is based on Singelton pattern. To get an instance you've to call this method. It then creates an object only once and returns the reference.

The difference to the default constructor is, the logging mechanism can be changed any time at runtime.

Parameters:
log - sets logging setting
Returns:
instance of error message

printMessage

public void printMessage(java.lang.Throwable e,
                         java.lang.String title)
Literally any subclass of throwable can be passed down here. With the exception object an message dialog will be created with as much information as available.

Parameters:
e - superclass of all errors and exceptions
title - the headline for the error dialog

printMessage

public void printMessage(java.lang.Throwable e,
                         java.lang.String title,
                         java.util.logging.Level level)
Literally any subclass of throwable can be passed down here. With the exception object an message dialog will be created with as much information as available.

Parameters:
e - superclass of all errors and exceptions
title - the headline for the error dialog
level - defines the logging level. It's a mechanism to make logging very flexible and cots very little at runtime when logging code is not used, e.g. in production. Available levels are:
  • ALL
    • enables logging of all records
  • SEVERE
    • intended for extremely important messages (highest value)
  • WARNING
    • intended for warning messages
  • INFO
    • informational runtime messages
  • CONFIG
    • informational messages about config/setup
  • FINE
    • greater detail; used for debugging
  • FINER
    • even greater detail
  • FINEST
    • greatest detail (lowest value)
  • OFF
    • turns logging off

printMessage

public void printMessage(java.lang.Throwable e,
                         java.lang.String message,
                         java.lang.String title)
Literally any subclass of throwable can be passed down here. With the exception object an message dialog will be created with as much information as available.

Parameters:
e - superclass of all errors and exceptions
message - customized messages can be passed down here.
title - the headline for the error dialog

printMessage

printMessage

public void printMessage(java.lang.Thread t,
                         java.lang.Throwable e,
                         java.lang.String title)
It's passed the thread t and the corresponding error or exception e. The thread is where the exception has occurred. That could be the EDT or any other thread. The object e is any throwable. Throwable is the superclass of any error or exception that can occur.

Parameters:
t - either the EDT or any other thread, like worker threads.
e - superclass of all errors and exceptions
title - the headline for the error dialog

printMessage

public void printMessage(java.lang.Thread t,
                         java.lang.Throwable e,
                         java.lang.String message,
                         java.lang.String title,
                         java.util.logging.Level level)
It's passed the thread t and the corresponding error or exception e. The thread is where the exception has occurred. That could be the EDT or any other thread. The object e is any throwable. Throwable is the superclass of any error or exception that can occur. There is a 3rd parameter called message. It is optional and can contain any detailed description about the failure like the stackTrace or any customized description.

Parameters:
t - either the EDT or any other thread, like worker threads.
e - superclass of all errors and exceptions
message - as the parameter already says: you've got the opportunity to put same custom information here in.
title - the headline for the error dialog
level - defines the logging level. It's a mechanism to make logging very flexible and cots very little at runtime when logging code is not used, e.g. in production. Available levels are:
  • ALL
    • enables logging of all records
  • SEVERE
    • intended for extremely important messages (highest value)
  • WARNING
    • intended for warning messages
  • INFO
    • informational runtime messages
  • CONFIG
    • informational messages about config/setup
  • FINE
    • greater detail; used for debugging
  • FINER
    • even greater detail
  • FINEST
    • greatest detail (lowest value)
  • OFF
    • turns logging off

ok

@Action
public void ok()
this method refers to the OK button. In contrast to closeDialog() it shuts down the whole system.

closeDialog

@Action
public void closeDialog()
this method refers to the Close button. It just closes the caused message dialog, but doesn't shut down the system.

isLoggingEnabled

public boolean isLoggingEnabled()
gets the current logging setting. The flag is actually not stored here, but in the controller layer. This method gets the flag from there and returns it to the invoker.

Returns:
logging?
